Award.AwardTitle: Advancing the Careers of Women in STEM at Predominantly Undergraduate Institutions through Professional Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the project is to create a sustainable network of women STEM faculty who work in small predominantly undergraduate institutions (PUIs) where isolation is particularly pronounced. This project proposes to create both horizontal and vertical mentoring for women STEM faculty at 12 PUIs across four STEM areas (i.e., Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science/ Engineering/physics, and Mathematics) The mentoring will target women early in their careers, mid-career, and at the senior level.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The proposers have done a very nice job of documenting the need for the mentoring program and leadership development among STEM women faculty at PUIs. They have done an excellent job of setting up a highly sustainable program thorough the cooperation of three national organizations. Each of the 12 participating institutions as well as the three organizations has submitted letters of support and commitment. Overall, this proposal is extremely well constructed. The PIs are well qualified to carry out the duties of this project.


BROADER IMPACTS

Through the mentoring and leadership activities 70 STEM women academics will be directly affected. In addition the proposers make a compelling case that the retention and increased job satisfaction of these faculty will have the potential to influence about 25,660 female undergraduate students who are in their classes. Additionally, the outcomes of this project, through traditional dissemination activities, conference activities, and the social networking components are positioned to impact broadly women STEM faculty at PUIs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Description

The goal of this project was to develop an effective, efficient, and sustainable network of female Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) faculty at Predominately Undergraduate Institutions (PUI). The project encouraged discipline-specific understanding and growth, expanded social and professional networks and opportunities, and nurtured career advancement.

The project team created a five-year replicable horizontal networking and vertical mentoring structure for 70 STEM women faculty members at 12 PUIs and provided leadership opportunities for more than 26 of the participants. The project involved participating faculty in each STEM discipline—Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Engineering, Mathematics, and Physics—and at each career level—early, mid-career, and senior—by organizing fourteen groups of four to six women who share both discipline and career level. Each of these groups met in three configurations: individually where group members discussed and planned career goals and mentored one another, with all other groups of the same career level for horizontal networking, and with all other groups within their discipline for two-way vertical mentoring. Each group also communicated via email, video conference, and phone.

During the project period, three all-participant meetings were held in conjunction with three national organizations: the Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR), the American Association of American Colleges & Universities (AAC&U), and Project Kaleidoscope (PKAL). One has a focus on undergraduate research, one on women and education, and one on STEM collaborations.

An Advisory Board of women leaders from the national organizations advised the project internal steering committee and assisted in providing a platform at their national meetings for project results dissemination. The project evaluators, who are social scientists, developed survey and qualitative research instruments and processes, assessed the networking/mentoring structure, content impact for individuals, and participation intensity. They also are assisting in the preparation of dissemination information such as reports for university presidents, conference presentations, and publications.

Intellectual Merit

Paradigmatic social change in higher education over the past 40 years has seen people of color, women, and other marginalized groups increasingly franchised as both administrators and academics. There has been voluminous higher education research on this significant culture change in both the social sciences and the humanities with commensurately less work being done in the sciences. This research will significantly add to that literature in its account of a group of 70 STEM women faculty employed in primarily undergraduate colleges and universities over 5 years as they met and discussed their experiences, aspirations, barriers, and strategies related to professional development, work-life balance, and career satisfaction and advancement. By reducing the isolation of faculty women, (who are still greatly underrepresented in STEM disciplines) and building leadership skills through workshops and readings as well as networking and mentoring, the project helped participating women expand their development and research options, secure more recognition for their work, advance in their careers through learning from others, and improve their student mentoring capabilities. Involving these women more deeply in STEM challenges related to the careers of women academics has resulted in them reporting greater synergy in problem-solving and innovation.

Broader Impacts

The enhanced career progression achieved via the project by each participant has and will continue to inspire more female undergraduate students to become STEM professionals, including becoming professors in PUIs. The 12 participating institutions include 134 total STEM women faculty who have influenced approximately 25,660 female undergraduates. Gender-based biases isolating STEM women at institutions were challenged both in project work group activities and more broadly and informally as participants brought new information and perspective back to their home institutions. Participants continue to report greater contact and mentoring activities with other women faculty both within and beyond their institutions as well as enhanced self-confidence. They also indicate an increased ability to identify and pursue external opportunities in their disciplines. Participants also report a greater efficacy in their teaching, expansion of their networks of social support and increased leadership roles and engagement in their home institutions.

This project has contributed to the national knowledge base on practices that can enhance the academic career advancement of women in science, technology, engineering, and math. This contribution has occurred through career development resources generated via the project and through sharing the assessment and recommendations on this peer mentoring approach. The data collected and results of the evaluations are being actively disseminated by the PI, the Internal Steering Committee, participants, and project leadership to various groups, including the institutional leadership of each participating institution, through multiple avenues including webinars, campus workshops, national organization meeting presentations, and publications.
